div.q: Thus we are taught in the prayer above, and may, ſaying it with the ſame ſpirit that made it, ſaint our ſelves, as is deſir'd we ſhould by the holy Ghoſt, who gave us this ſainting prayer for that holy purpoſe.

div.head: The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God, who on this day haſt taught the hearts of the Faithful by the Illumination of the holy Ghoſt, grant unto us in the ſame ſpirit to reliſh thoſe things that are right, and ever to rejoyce in his Conſolation.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: SAyntifie we beſeech thee, O Lord, our offered gifts: and mundifie our hearts by the Illuſtration of the Holy Ghoſt.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: LEt the infuſion of the Holy Ghoſt, O Lord, purifie our hearts, and fertilize them by the inward aſperſion of his heavenly dew.

div.head: The firſt Prayer.
div.p: ALmighty, everlaſting God, who haſt granted to thy ſervants in confeſſion of the true Faith to acknowledge the glory of the eternal Trinity, and in the power of Majeſtie to adore unity, we beſeech thee heartily that in the firmneſſe of the ſame Faith we may ever be defended from all adverſity.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: SAyntifie we beſeech thee, our Lord God, by the invocation of thy holy name the Hoſte of this oblation, and render us thereby unto thy ſelf an eternal preſent.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: GRant, O Lord God, that the receiving of this Sacrament, and the confeſſion of the ſempiternal Holy Trinity, and of the undivided unity thereof, may avail us to the health both of our body and ſoul.

div.head: On the firſt Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God, the ſtrength of thoſe that truſt in thee, be mercifully preſent to our prayers, and becauſe without thee mortal infirmity is of no ability, grant the aſſiſtance of thy grace, that in doing what thou doſt command, we may pleaſe thee both in word and will.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: VOuchſafe appeaſed we pray thee to accept of theſe our offerings dedicated to thee, O Lord, and grant that unto us they may afford perpetual help.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: BEing filled with ſo great gifts, grant, O Lord, we beſeech thee, that while we receive theſe wholſome boones, we may never ceaſe from praiſing thee.

div.head: On Sunday within the Octaves of Corpus Chriſti: being the ſecond after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: MAke us, O Lord, equally to have both a continual fear and love of thy holy name, becauſe thou doſt never leave them deſtitute of thy government, whom thou doeſt inſtruct in the ſolidity of thy Love.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: MAy this oblation ſacred to thy name purifie us, O Lord, we beſeech thee; and from day to day carry us to ſuch actions as conduce unto our heavenly life.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: NOw that we have received thy ſacred gifts, we beſeech thee, O Lord, that together with frequenting this myſterie, the effect of our ſalvation may increaſe.

div.head: On the third Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God who art the Protectour of thoſe that hope in thee, without whom nothing is valid, nothing is holy, multiply, we beſeech thee, over us thy mercy, that thou being our ruler, thou our guide, we may ſo paſſe by the temporal goods of this world, as not to looſe the eternal of the next.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: LOok, we beſeech thee, O Lord, upon the offerings of thy ſuppliant Church, and grant that what we are to receive may by perpetual ſanctification prove unto the health of thy believing people.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: MAy thy holy things, O Lord, received quicken us and prepare us (being expiated) for thy everlaſting mercy.

div.head: On the fourth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: GRant us, O Lord, we beſeech thee, that by thy order our courſe in this world may be peaceably directed, and that thy Church may enjoy a quiet devotion.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: BE pacified, O Lord, we beſeech thee, having received our oblations; and propitiouſly compell unto thee our even rebellious wills.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: MAy the received myſteries, O Lord, purifie us, and by their bounty defend us.

div.head: On the fifth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God who haſt prepared inviſible good things for thoſe that love thee; infuſe into our hearts the deſire of thy love, that loving thee in all things, and above them all, we may attain unto thy promiſes, which ſurpaſſe even all our deſires.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: BE, O Lord, propitious upon our ſupplications, and take unto thee benignely theſe offerings of thy ſervants of both ſexes; that what every one hath preſented in honour of thy name, may profit all of us to our ſalvation.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: WHom thou, O Lord, haſt filled with thy heavenly gifts, grant we beſeech thee, that we may be cleanſed from our hidden ſinnes, and delivered from the ſnares of our enemies.

div.head: On the ſixth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God of powers, to whom all belongs that is beſt, ingraft in our breaſts the love of thy holy name, and grant in us the increaſe of Religion; that thou mayeſt nouriſh thoſe things which are good, and (being ſo nouriſhed) maintain them by the practiſe of pietie.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: TAke unto thee, O Lord, benignely theſe oblations of thy people, and be propitious upon our ſupplications; and that no ones deſires be fruſtrate, no ones requeſt in vain, grant we beſeech thee that what we ask faithfully, we may obtain efficaciouſly.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: WE are, O Lord, full with thy gifts; we beſeech thee grant that we may be cleanſed by their effect, and defended by their help.

div.head: On the ſeventh Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God, whoſe providence is ſo diſpoſed as it never can be fruſtrated, remove, we humbly beſeech thee, all things that are hurtfull, and grant whatſoever may be beneficiall unto us.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: O God, who haſt concluded the diverſity of the legall hoſts under the perfection of one ſacrifice, receive the ſame from thy devout people, and ſanctifie it as thou diddeſt the offerings of Abel; that what every one tenders thee in honour of thy Majeſty, may avail to the health of us all.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: MAy thy medicinall operation clemently free us from our perverſities, and bring us to thoſe things that are right.

div.head: On the eighth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The first Prayer.
div.p: GRant us, O Lord we beſeech thee, propitiouſly the ſpirit of thinking, and doing what is right, that as we cannot be without thee, ſo we may live unto thee.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: REceive, O Lord we beſeech thee, what of thy bounty we bring unto thee: that theſe ſacred myſteries, by the operative power of thy grace, may ſanctifie us in the converſation of this preſent life, and lead us to eternall joyes.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: BE, O Lord, unto us this heavenly myſtery a reparation both of ſoul and body, that whoſe worſhip we perform his effect we may feel.

div.head: On the ninth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: LEt the ears of thy mercy, O Lord, be open to the prayers of thy ſuppliants: and to the end thou mayſt grant the things deſired to thoſe that ask, make them ask ſuch things as to thee are pleaſing.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: GRant unto us, O Lord, we beſeech thee, that we may worthily frequent theſe myſteries, becauſe as often as the commemoration of this Hoſte is celebrated, the work of our Redemption is exerciſed.

div.head: The post-Communion.
div.p: VVE pray, O Lord, that the communion of thy Sacrament may confer purity, and give unto us unity.

div.head: On the tenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God, who doeſt manifeſt thy Omnipotence moſt of all by pardoning and taking pitty, multiply upon us thy mercy, that we running unto thy promiſes, thou maiſt make us partakers of thy Heavenly Treaſures.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: BE the conſecrated ſacrifices rendered unto thee, O Lord, which thou haſt granted us ſo to be offered in honour of thy name, that withall thou haſt allowed them to be remedies unto us.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: VVE beſeech thee our Lord God, that whom thou doſt not ceaſe to repair with divine Sacraments, thou wilt not deprive them of thy favours being as thou art benigne.

div.head: On the eleventh Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The first Prayer.
div.p: ALmighty everlaſting God, who, out of the abundance of thy pity, doeſt exceed as well the merits of thy ſuppliants, as their deſires; pour out thy mercy upon us, that thou maiſt forgive what our conſcience is afraid of, and add even what our prayers dare not preſume to ask.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: LOok we beſeech thee, O Lord, propitiouſly upon our ſervice, that what we offer may be to thee an acceptable gift, and to our frailty a ſupport.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: MAy we find, O Lord we beſeech thee, by the receiving thy Sacrament help of ſoul and body; that beeing in both preſerved we may glory in the plenitude of the heavenly remedy.

div.head: On the twelfth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The first Prayer.
div.p: OMnipotent and moſt mercifull God, from whoſe bounty it proceedeth that of thy faithful people thou art worthily and laudably ſerved, grant unto us, we beſeech thee, that we may runne unto thy promiſes without offence.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: LOok, we beſeech thee O Lord, propitiouſly upon the hoſts which on thy holy altars we offer unto thee, that giving us pardon, they may alſo give honour unto thy Name.

div.head: The post-Communion.
div.p: LEt the holy participation of this myſtery quicken us, O Lord we beſeech thee, and equally give unto us expiation, and defence.

div.head: On the thirteenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: ALlmighty and everlaſting God, give unto us the increaſe of Faith, Hope, and Charity; and that we may deſerve to obtain what thou doeſt promiſe, make us love what thou doeſt command.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: BE propitious, O Lord we beſeech thee, unto thy people, and to their offerings, that appeaſed by this oblation thou both pardon us, and grant us our requeſts.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: HAving, O Lord, received the heavenly Sacraments, we beſeech thee let them avail us to the increaſe of our eternall Redemption.

div.head: On the fourteenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: KEep, we beſeech thee, O Lord, thy Church with perpetuall propitiation; and ſince without thee humane mortality faileth, let it alwayes by thy help be withdrawn from ſuch things as are hurtfull, and directed to thoſe that are ſaving.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: GRant unto us, we pray thee O Lord, that this wholſome offering may be a purgation of our ſinnes, and a propitiation of thy power.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: LEt thy Sacraments, O God, alwayes cleanſe us, and bring us to the effect of our eternall ſalvation.

div.head: On the fifteenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: LEt thy continual mercy, O Lord, both cleanſe and defend thy Church, and becauſe without thee it cannot ſtand ſecurely, be it alwayes governed by thy bounty.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: LEt thy Sacraments, O Lord, keep us and alwayes defend us from the aſſaults of the devil.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: VVE beſeech thee, O Lord, let the operation of thy heavenly gift poſſeſſe our minds and bodies, that not our ſenſe in us, but continually the effect of thy ſaid gift may prevent us.

div.head: On the ſixteenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: LEt thy Grace, we beſeech thee O Lord, alwayes go before, and follow us, and make us continually intent unto good works.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: CLeanſe us, O Lord, we beſeech thee, by the effect of this preſent ſacrifice, and mercifully work in us that we may be ſharers of the ſame.

div.head: The post-Communion.
div.p: VVE pray thee, O Lord, to purifie benignely our ſouls, and to renew them with thy heavenly Sacraments, that conſequently we may have both preſent and future helps for our bodies.

div.head: On the ſeventeenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: GRant, we beſeech thee, O Lord, that thy people may flye Diabolical contagion, and follow thee, (the onely God) with pure intention.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: O Lord, we humbly beſeech thy Majeſtie that theſe holy things which we bear about us, may diveſt us of our preſent and future offences.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: BY thy ſanctifications, Almighty God, be our ſins cured, and may eternal remedies accrue unto us.

div.head: On the eighteenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: LEt, O Lord, the operation of thy mercy direct our hearts, becauſe without thee we cannot pleaſe thee.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: O God, who by the venerable commerce of this ſacrifice doſt make us partakers of thy onely and higheſt Deity, grant we beſeech thee that as we acknowledge thy truth, ſo we may by our behoofeful comportment attain the ſame.

div.head: The post-Communion.
div.p: WE give thee thanks, O Lord, for being nouriſhed by thy ſacred bounty, beſeeching thy mercy that thou wilt make us worthy to partake thereof.

div.head: On the nineteenth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: ALmighty and mercifull God, vouchſafe propitiouſly to exclude all things which are adverſe unto us, that being ſet at liberty both in mind and body, we may with free ſouls execute thoſe things that appertain unto thee.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: THeſe offerings which we make in the ſight of thy Majeſtie, grant, O Lord we beſeech thee, that they may be ſaving unto us.

div.head: The post-Communion.
div.p: MAy thy medicinall operation, O Lord, clemently free us from our perverſities, and make us alwayes adhere to thy commands.

div.head: On the twentieth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: VVE beſeech thee O Lord, (thou being pacified) grant unto thy faithfull people pardon and peace, that they may be both clean from all offences, and ſerve thee with ſecured ſouls.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: WE pray thee, O Lord, to let theſe myſteries afford us heavenly remedy, and to purge away the ſinnes of our heart.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: THat we may be rendred worthy of thy ſacred gifts, we beſeech thee, O Lord, make us alwayes obey thy commandments.

div.head: On the one and twentieth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: PReſerve, we beſeech thee O Lord, thy Family with continuall Pietie, that thou protecting it may be free from all adverſitie, and in good works reſt devoted to thy holy Name.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: REceive, O Lord, propitiouſly thoſe hoſts by which thou wilt have thy ſelf appeaſed, and health given unto us by thy mightie power.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: HAving gotten the nouriſhment of Immortalitie, grant, we beſeech thee O Lord, that what we have received with our mouths, we may follow with pure ſouls.

div.head: On the two and twentieth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: O God, our refuge and ſtrength, be preſent (thou the Authour of piety) to the godly Prayers of thy Church, and grant that what we ask faithfully we may obtain effectually.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: GRant, moſt mercifull God, that this wholſome oblation may inceſſantly free us from our own guilt, and defend us from all adverſities.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: WE have received, O Lord, the gifts of thy ſacred myſterie, humbly beſeeching thee, that what thou haſt commanded us to do in memory of thee may avail to the help of our infirmitie.

div.head: On the three and twentieth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: PArdon, we beſeech thee O Lord, the offences of thy people, that from the bonds of our ſins (which through our frailty we have committed) by thy bounty we may be delivered.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: WE offer unto thee, O Lord, for the increaſe of our dutie the ſacrifice of praiſe, that what thou haſt given to the unworthy, thou wilt propitiouſly make it availing.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: WE beſeech thee, Almightie God, that whom thou haſt made glad with the divine participation, thou wilt not permit them to be ſubject unto humane dangers.

div.head: On the four and twentieth Sunday after Pentecoſt.
The firſt Prayer.
div.p: STirre up, we beſeech thee, O Lord, the wills of thy Faithful, that they more diligently preparing the fruit of thy divine work, may receive the greater benefits of thy mercy.

div.head: The Secret.
div.p: BE, O Lord, propitious unto our ſupplications, and receiving both the oblations and prayers of thy people, convert unto thee all our hearts, that being freed from earthly deſires, we may betake our ſelves to heavenly wiſhes.

div.head: The poſt-Communion.
div.p: GRant unto us, we beſeech thee O Lord, that by theſe Sacraments which we have received, whatſoever is vitiated in our ſouls, may be cured by the gift of their medicinall virtue.
